content: There are more incorrect ways to become an AI engineer than correct ones, by at least an order of magnitude.

To avoid wasting time, focus on learning only the essential fundamentals for an AI engineer: what a neural net is, how transformer architecture works, how to train a basic model, fine-tune a small LLM, and understand LLM/AI agent terminology.
It is not necessary for an AI engineer to be able to calculate the chain rule by hand or implement backpropagation from scratch.
While learning math is useful for areas like ML research or personal curiosity, it is not strictly necessary for AI engineering.
In AI engineering practice, one must think in terms of systems (including security, architecture, scaling, and production) rather than solely focusing on models.

When building a portfolio for AI engineering, create personal projects that mimic real-world applications by incorporating aspects like evaluation, observability, deployment, and security, rather than just tutorial-based dummy projects.
The AI landscape is rapidly changing, making it impossible and frustrating to try and keep up with every new tool release or framework.
Instead of trying to keep up with every new AI tool, allow new tools and hypes to prove their value over time before investing in them.
The goal in learning AI engineering should be to develop a mental model of how things fundamentally work, rather than attempting to use every possible tool.
When using roadmaps for AI engineering, treat them as a list of topics to learn from various resources rather than a rigid guide to follow word-for-word.

To effectively network for AI engineering jobs, focus on positioning yourself to get future leads, such as connecting with people on LinkedIn/X, engaging in cold outreach correctly, or building a profile on X to share your work.
